Award Type: COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT (B)
Description: THE USE OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICE VALUATION WITHIN USDA: ADVANCING THE SCIENCE - RANGELAND ECOSYSTEM DYSFUNCTION ASSOCIATED WITH INCREASED WILDFIRE ACTIVITY, INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES, AND EXPANDING CONIFERS IS NEGATIVELY IMPACTING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND A VARIETY OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES ACROSS THE WESTERN UNITED STATES. THESE FACTORS HAVE SEVERE ECONOMIC IMPLICATIONS; FOR EXAMPLE, FEDERAL FIRE SUPPRESSION EXPENDITURES IN FY 2017 APPROACHED $3 BILLION. THE INCREASING FREQUENCY OF WILDFIRES ACROSS WESTERN RANGELANDS REMAINS A THREAT TO ECOSYSTEM STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION. IN GREAT BASIN RANGELANDS, WILDFIRE OFTEN CREATES A POSITIVE FEEDBACK BY INCREASING INVASIVE ANNUALS AND ALTERING FUEL LOADING. UNDERSTANDING THE DYNAMICS OF THE PLANT COMMUNITY-BOTH IN RESPONSE TO WILDFIRE AND ITS ROLE IN WILDFIRE OCCURRENCE-IS CRITICAL TO GUIDE RANGELAND MANAGEMENT IN THE FACE OF FIRE, FUELS, AND INVASIVE PLANTS. AT LARGE SPATIAL SCALES, EXISTING FUEL MODELING EFFORTS HAVE SHOWN THAT ANTECEDENT PRECIPITATION AMOUNT AND PATTERN CAN BE USED TO GENERALIZE WILDFIRE PROBABILITY. MISSING FROM THOSE EFFORTS HAS BEEN THE INCORPORATION OF BIOTIC STATUS (E.G., PLANT COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AND FUNCTIONAL GROUP ABUNDANCE) INTO PREDICTIVE MODELS. INCORPORATING CURRENT BIOTIC INFORMATION HAS THE POTENTIAL TO DRAMATICALLY IMPROVE THE RELEVANCY OF EMPIRICALLY-DERIVED MODELS TO ON-THE-GROUND MANAGEMENT CONDITIONS AND DECISION MAKING. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS WORK ARE TO 1) EXAMINE THE BIOTIC DRIVERS OF AND RESPONSES TO WILDFIRE; AND 2) EXAMINE THE POTENTIAL FOR INCORPORATING BIOTIC COMPONENTS INTO ABIOTICALLY-DRIVEN (E.G., PRECIPITATION AT VARIOUS TIME LAGS) MODELS FOR PREDICTING WILDFIRE AND PLANT COMMUNITY RESPONSES. OBJECTIVES WILL APPLY ACROSS THE GREAT BASIN REGION.

Award Type: OTHER REIMBURSABLE, CONTINGENT, INTANGIBLE, OR INDIRECT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE
Description: SURVIVAL AND GROWTH OF BEGINNING FARMERS - RANGELAND ECOSYSTEM DYSFUNCTION ASSOCIATED WITH INCREASED WILDFIRE ACTIVITY, INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES, AND EXPANDING CONIFERS IS NEGATIVELY IMPACTING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND A VARIETY OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES ACROSS THE WESTERN UNITED STATES. THESE FACTORS HAVE SEVERE ECONOMIC IMPLICATIONS; FOR EXAMPLE, FEDERAL FIRE SUPPRESSION EXPENDITURES IN FY 2017 APPROACHED $3 BILLION. THE INCREASING FREQUENCY OF WILDFIRES ACROSS WESTERN RANGELANDS REMAINS A THREAT TO ECOSYSTEM STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION. IN GREAT BASIN RANGELANDS, WILDFIRE OFTEN CREATES A POSITIVE FEEDBACK BY INCREASING INVASIVE ANNUALS AND ALTERING FUEL LOADING. UNDERSTANDING THE DYNAMICS OF THE PLANT COMMUNITY-BOTH IN RESPONSE TO WILDFIRE AND ITS ROLE IN WILDFIRE OCCURRENCE-IS CRITICAL TO GUIDE RANGELAND MANAGEMENT IN THE FACE OF FIRE, FUELS, AND INVASIVE PLANTS. AT LARGE SPATIAL SCALES, EXISTING FUEL MODELING EFFORTS HAVE SHOWN THAT ANTECEDENT PRECIPITATION AMOUNT AND PATTERN CAN BEUSED TO GENERALIZE WILDFIRE PROBABILITY. MISSING FROM THOSE EFFORTS HAS BEEN THE INCORPORATION OF BIOTIC STATUS (E.G., PLANT COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AND FUNCTIONAL GROUP ABUNDANCE) INTO PREDICTIVE MODELS. INCORPORATING CURRENT BIOTIC INFORMATION HAS THE POTENTIAL TO DRAMATICALLY IMPROVE THE RELEVANCY OF EMPIRICALLY-DERIVED MODELS TO ON-THE-GROUND MANAGEMENT CONDITIONS AND DECISION MAKING. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS WORK ARE TO 1) EXAMINE THE BIOTIC DRIVERS OF AND RESPONSES TO WILDFIRE; AND 2) EXAMINE THE POTENTIAL FOR INCORPORATING BIOTIC COMPONENTS INTO ABIOTICALLY-DRIVEN (E.G., PRECIPITATION AT VARIOUS TIME LAGS) MODELS FOR PREDICTING WILDFIRE AND PLANT COMMUNITY RESPONSES. OBJECTIVES WILL APPLY ACROSS THE GREAT BASIN REGION.

Description: IMPROVING AND EXPANDING FOOD PRICE FORECASTS AT ERS - THE PURPOSE OF THE CURRENT PROJECT IS TO INVESTIGATE THE BIOCHEMICAL COMPOSITION OF ANAEROBIC SOIL DISINFESTATION (ASD)-TREATED SOIL SAMPLES USING HIGH-RESOLUTION NUCLEAR MAGNETIC RESONANCE (NMR). A SYNERGISTIC APPROACH INVOLVING THE DEVELOPMENT OF SUSTAINABLE AGRICULTURAL PRACTICES AND NMR ASSESSMENT OF METABOLITE PROFILES IS UTILIZED TO IDENTIFY NEW ANTIMICROBIAL COMPOUNDS IN THE SOIL. THIS WORK SEEKS TO: 1) IDENTIFY METABOLIC COMPOUNDS AND OTHER NOVEL BIOACTIVE METABOLITES PRESENT IN SOIL SAMPLES SUBJECTED TO ASD USING NMR; 2) DETERMINE THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE BIOCHEMICAL COMPOSITION AND PATHOGEN SUPPRESSIVE PROPERTIES OF ASD-TREATED SOILS. THE INNOVATION OF THIS APPROACH IS THAT NMR OFFERS THE POTENTIAL TO DETERMINE THE THREE-DIMENSIONAL STRUCTURE OF NOVEL METABOLITES IDENTIFIED IN ASD-TREATED SOILS ALLOWS FOR DETAILED UNDERSTANDING OF ANTIMICROBIAL MECHANISMS IN THESE AGRICULTURAL SYSTEMS.

Award Type: OTHER REIMBURSABLE, CONTINGENT, INTANGIBLE, OR INDIRECT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE
Description: ASSESSING POTENTIAL INFLUENCES OF INCOME GROWTH ON GLOBAL PATTERNS IN FOODBORNE DISEASE - RANGELAND ECOSYSTEM DYSFUNCTION ASSOCIATED WITH INCREASED WILDFIRE ACTIVITY, INVASIVE ANNUAL GRASSES, AND EXPANDING CONIFERS IS NEGATIVELY IMPACTING AGRICULTURAL PRODUCTION AND A VARIETY OF ECOSYSTEM SERVICES ACROSS THE WESTERN UNITED STATES. THESE FACTORS HAVE SEVERE ECONOMIC IMPLICATIONS; FOR EXAMPLE, FEDERAL FIRE SUPPRESSION EXPENDITURES IN FY 2017 APPROACHED $3 BILLION. THE INCREASING FREQUENCY OF WILDFIRES ACROSS WESTERN RANGELANDS REMAINS A THREAT TO ECOSYSTEM STRUCTURE AND FUNCTION. IN GREAT BASIN RANGELANDS, WILDFIRE OFTEN CREATES A POSITIVE FEEDBACK BY INCREASING INVASIVE ANNUALS AND ALTERING FUEL LOADING. UNDERSTANDING THE DYNAMICS OF THE PLANT COMMUNITY-BOTH IN RESPONSE TO WILDFIRE AND ITS ROLE IN WILDFIRE OCCURRENCE-IS CRITICAL TO GUIDE RANGELAND MANAGEMENT IN THE FACE OF FIRE, FUELS, AND INVASIVE PLANTS. AT LARGE SPATIAL SCALES, EXISTING FUEL MODELING EFFORTS HAVE SHOWN THAT ANTECEDENT PRECIPITATION AMOUNT AND PATTERN CAN BE USED TO GENERALIZE WILDFIRE PROBABILITY. MISSING FROM THOSE EFFORTS HAS BEEN THE INCORPORATION OF BIOTIC STATUS (E.G., PLANT COMMUNITY COMPOSITION AND FUNCTIONAL GROUP ABUNDANCE) INTO PREDICTIVE MODELS. INCORPORATING CURRENT BIOTIC INFORMATION HAS THE POTENTIAL TO DRAMATICALLY IMPROVE THE RELEVANCY OF EMPIRICALLY-DERIVED MODELS TO ON-THE-GROUND MANAGEMENT CONDITIONS AND DECISION MAKING. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS WORK ARE TO 1) EXAMINE THE BIOTIC DRIVERS OF AND RESPONSES TO WILDFIRE; AND 2) EXAMINE THE POTENTIAL FOR INCORPORATING BIOTIC COMPONENTS INTO ABIOTICALLY-DRIVEN (E.G., PRECIPITATION AT VARIOUS TIME LAGS) MODELS FOR PREDICTING WILDFIRE AND PLANT COMMUNITY RESPONSES. OBJECTIVES WILL APPLY ACROSS THE GREAT BASIN REGION.

INCORPORATING CURRENT BIOTIC INFORMATION HAS THE POTENTIAL TO DRAMATICALLY IMPROVE THE RELEVANCY OF EMPIRICALLY-DERIVED MODELS TO ON-THE-GROUND MANAGEMENT CONDITIONS AND DECISION MAKING. THE OBJECTIVES OF THIS WORK ARE TO 1) EXAMINE THE BIOTIC DRIVERS OF AND RESPONSES TO WILDFIRE; AND 2) EXAMINE THE POTENTIAL FOR INCORPORATING BIOTIC COMPONENTS INTO ABIOTICALLY-DRIVEN (E.G., PRECIPITATION AT VARIOUS TIME LAGS) MODELS FOR PREDICTING WILDFIRE AND PLANT COMMUNITY RESPONSES. OBJECTIVES WILL APPLY ACROSS THE GREAT BASIN REGION.

Award Type: OTHER REIMBURSABLE, CONTINGENT, INTANGIBLE, OR INDIRECT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE
Description: SPS MEASURES AND THE DURATION AND HAZARD RATES OF U.S. AGRICULTURAL EXPORTS: A COMPREHENSIVE EMPIRICAL ASSESSMENT - INFECTIONS WITH HERPES VIRUSES ARE KNOWN TO GENERATE POWERFUL CD8 T CELL RESPONSES AND THERE IS A LARGE BODY OF EVIDENCE INDICATING THAT THESE RESPONSES PLAY A KEY ROLE IN IMMUNITY TO THESE VIRUSES. THIS HAS PROMPTED RESEARCH TO EXPLORE THE POTENTIAL OF CERTAIN HERPES VIRUSES AS VACCINE VECTORS, FOCUSING PARTICULARLY ON DISEASES THAT REQUIRE CD8 T CELL RESPONSES FOR IMMUNITY. THE CAPACITY OF CD8 T CELLS TO ACT AS EFFECTORS AGAINST VIRAL INFECTIONS GENERALLY RELIES ON THEIR ABILITY TO RECOGNISE AND RESPOND TO VIRUS-INFECTED CELLS BEFORE THEY PRODUCE LARGE QUANTITIES OF VIRUS. IN THIS REGARD, CD8 T CELL RESPONSES TO HERPES VIRUSES SUCH AS HUMAN HERPES SIMPLEX VIRUS (HSV-1) TEND TO INCLUDE DOMINANT RESPONSES AGAINST THE IE PROTEINS AND IT IS THESE RESPONSES THAT ARE PREDOMINANTLY INVOLVED IN MEDIATING IMMUNE PROTECTION. IN ADDITION, A NUMBER OF HERPES VIRUSES HAVE A PREFERENTIAL TROPISM FOR MACROPHAGES AND DENDRITIC CELLS, THUS ENABLING THE INFECTED CELLS THEMSELVES TO ACT AS ANTIGEN-PRESENTING CELLS FOR INDUCTION OF CD8 T CELL RESPONSES. ONE SUCH GROUP IS THE CYTOMEGALOVIRUSES (CMV), WHICH IN HUMANS CAUSE ASYMPTOMATIC INFECTIONS IN HEALTHY PEOPLE BUT CAN BE PATHOGENIC IN IMMUNOCOMPROMISED INDIVIDUALS. MOREOVER, SINCE CMVS ARE POOR INDUCERS OF NEUTRALISING ANTIBODIES, A CD8 T CELL RESPONSE CAN STILL BE INDUCED FOLLOWING IMMUNIZATION OF PREVIOUSLY INFECTED INDIVIDUALS. THE COMBINATION OF THESE PROPERTIES MAKES CMVS AN ATTRACTIVE PROSPECT FOR USE AS VACCINE VECTORS. RECENT STUDIES UTILISING SIMIAN CMV AS A VECTOR FOR DELIVERY OF SIMIAN IMMUNODEFICIENCY VIRAL ANTIGENS HAVE SHOWN THAT IT INDUCES STRONG VIRUS-SPECIFIC CD8 T CELL RESPONSES AND HIGH LEVELS OF PROTECTION AGAINST VIRUS CHALLENGE. ALTHOUGH A CYTOMEGALOVIRUS HAS NOT BEEN IDENTIFIED IN CATTLE, BOVINE HERPES VIRUS 4 (BHV-4) SHARES A NUMBER OF PROPERTIES WITH CYTOMEGALOVIRUSES, WHICH HIGHLIGHT ITS POTENTIAL AS A VECTOR. ORIGINALLY CLASSIFIED AS A B-HERPES VIRUS AND REFERRED TO AS BOVINE CYTOMEGALOVIRUS, BASED ON ITS BIOLOGICAL PROPERTIES, BHV-4 WAS SUBSEQUENTLY FOUND TO BE A '-HERPES VIRUS. INFECTION WITH BHV-4 IS PREVALENT IN EUROPE AND USA AND ALTHOUGH THE VIRUS HAS BEEN ISOLATED FREQUENTLY FROM BOTH NORMAL AND DISEASED BOVINE TISSUES, THERE IS CURRENTLY NO EVIDENCE THAT IT IS THE CAUSATIVE AGENT OF DISEASE. LIKE CYTOMEGALOVIRUSES, BHV-4 IS REPORTED TO HAVE A PREDILECTION FOR THE MACROPHAGE LINEAGE AND IT INDUCES POOR NEUTRALIZING ANTIBODY RESPONSES. HENCE, IT IS LIKELY TO GENERATE CELLULAR IMMUNE RESPONSES IN PREVIOUSLY INFECTED ANIMALS AND COULD POTENTIALLY BE ADMINISTERED ON MORE THAN ONE OCCASION TO BOOST CELLULAR IMMUNE RESPONSES. BHV-4 HAS BEEN DEVELOPED AS A VACCINE VECTOR BY DR. GAITANO DONOFRIA, WHO HAS PRODUCED SEVERAL RECOMBINANT BHV-4 VIRUSES EXPRESSING VIRAL PROTEINS AND SHOWN THAT THEY STIMULATE STRONG ANTIBODY RESPONSES IN CALVES AND PROTECTION AGAINST THE RESPECTIVE VIRUSES. HOWEVER, THE ABILITY OF THE VIRUS TO INDUCE CELLULAR IMMUNE RESPONSES HAS NOT BEEN INVESTIGATED.

Award Type: OTHER REIMBURSABLE, CONTINGENT, INTANGIBLE, OR INDIRECT FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE
Description: THE IMPACT OF NAFTA AND KORUS U.S. AGRICULTURAL TRADE: ESTIMATES USING THE SYNTHETIC CONTROL METHOD - PREVIOUS WORK HAS IDENTIFIED MOST (OR ALL) OF THE EFFECTORS THAT PSEUDOMONAS SYRINGAE STRAIN DC3000 USES TO DISABLE PLANT DEFENSES AND MANY OF THE COMPONENTS IN THE PLANT DEFENSE SYSTEMS THAT ARE TARGETED BY THE EFFECTORS. HOWEVER, IT IS STILL RELATIVELY UNKNOWN WHICH COMPONENTS OF THE PLANT ENVIRONMENT TRIGGER THE BACTERIA TO DEPLOY ITS VIRULENCE SYSTEMS, OR HOW THE BACTERIA SENSES AND RESPONDS TO PLANT DEFENSES WHEN THEY ARE DEPLOYED. THIS AGREEMENT PROPOSES TO IDENTIFY THE SIGNAL RECEPTORS AND REGULATION PATHWAYS THAT DC3000 USES TO SURVIVE WITHIN THE PLANT ENVIRONMENT.

Description: THE AG ECON SCHOLARS MENTORING PROGRAM - GRAPEVINE COLD HARDINESS IS A COMPLEX TRAIT WHICH BEGINS IN FALL AS VINES ACCLIMATE AND CONCLUDES IN SPRING FOLLOWING BUDBURST. AS A RESULT, THE PHENOLOGICAL PROGRESSION DURING THE GROWING SEASON CAN IMPACT THE VINE'S PREPAREDNESS FOR WINTER. SIMILARLY, VERY COLD HARDY WILD GRAPEVINES CAN BURST VERY LATE IN THE SPRING, PREVENTING FROST DAMAGE. HOWEVER, THESE SAME VINES THEN DO NOT RIPEN AND ARE NOT READY FOR FALL. UNDERSTANDING THE GENETIC ARCHITECTURE OF PHENOLOGY IS THUS VERY IMPORTANT FOR COMBINING ESSENTIAL TRAITS IN NEW HYBRID GRAPEVINES.

Description: UPDATING THE ERS AGRICULTURAL TRADE MULTIPLIERS - GRAPEVINE COLD HARDINESS IS A COMPLEX TRAIT WHICH BEGINS IN FALL AS VINES ACCLIMATE AND CONCLUDES IN SPRING FOLLOWING BUDBURST. AS A RESULT, THE PHENOLOGICAL PROGRESSION DURING THE GROWING SEASON CAN IMPACT THE VINE'S PREPAREDNESS FOR WINTER. SIMILARLY, VERY COLD HARDY WILD GRAPEVINES CAN BURST VERY LATE IN THE SPRING, PREVENTING FROST DAMAGE. HOWEVER, THESE SAME VINES THEN DO NOT RIPEN AND ARE NOT READY FOR FALL. UNDERSTANDING THE GENETIC ARCHITECTURE OF PHENOLOGY IS THUS VERY IMPORTANT FOR COMBINING ESSENTIAL TRAITS IN NEW HYBRID GRAPEVINES.
